review.title: Data Analytics using Ontologies of Management Theories: Towards Implementing 'From Theory to Practice'
review.abstract: We explore how computational ontologies can be impactful vis-a-vis the developing discipline of "data science." We posit an approach wherein management theories are represented as formal axioms, and then applied to draw inferences about data that reside in corporate databases. That is, management theories would be implemented as rules within a data analytics engine. We demonstrate a case study development of such an ontology by formally representing an accounting theory in First-Order Logic. Though quite preliminary, the idea that an information technology, namely ontologies, can potentially actualize the academic cliche, "From Theory to Practice," and be applicable to the burgeoning domain of data analytics is novel and exciting.

If the manager is opportunistic in their treatment of accounting elements, the auditor can negotiate with them about advice.

sections.heading: 4. Summary and Future Work
sections.text: In this paper we postulate that the operationalization of management theories as ontologies is novel and feasible. We then demonstrate a case study development of an auditor decision-making ontology using an already existing, YODA @ ssb Belief-Desires-Intention (BDI) ontology. We also postulate that such operationalization may be useful because automated conclusions can be used as data analysis methods using theories. Moreover, this concept is very preliminary and there are many potential obstacles to its further development. It may be that most management hypotheses are so abstract that they cannot be applied concretely to real data without unrealistic assumptions.
